sentences.sentence: There is a lady, it seems, called Mrs. Younge, who was some time ago governess( 家庭教师 ) to Miss Darcy, who was then dismissed( 解雇 ) in disgrace( 耻辱 ), though Mr. Darcy did not explain why.
She then took a large house in Edward-street, and has earned her living( 谋生 ) by renting( 租 ) out rooms.
He knew that Mrs. Younge knew Wickham well, and he went to her for news of him as soon as he got to town.
But it was two or three days before he could get from her what he wanted.
She would not betray( 背叛 ) Wickham’s trust in her, I suppose, without bribery( 贿赂 ) and corruption( 腐败 ), for she really did know where her friend was to be found.
At length our kind friend managed to get their address.
He saw Wickham, and afterward( 之后 ) insisted on seeing Lydia.
At first he tried to persuade her to quit( 离开 ) her present disgraceful( 耻辱的 ) situation.
But she would not hear of leaving Wickham.
She was sure they should be married some time or other, and it did not much matter when.
Since such were her feelings( 感受 ), it only remained, he thought, to arrange a marriage,
which, in his very first conversation with Wickham, he easily learnt had never been Wickham’s plan.
He confessed( 坦白 ) that he had had to leave the regiment( 团 ) because of some serious gambling( 赌博 ) debts, and said that Lydia had only herself to blame for any damage to her reputation( 名誉 ).
As to his future, he had no definite( 明确的 ) plans.
Mr. Darcy asked Wickham why he had not married your sister at once.
Though nobody would have assumed( 认为 ) that Mr. Bennet was very rich, he would have at least been able to give something to Wickham, if he had agreed to marry Lydia.
But Mr. Darcy found, in reply to this question, that Wickham still hoped that he could find better success by marrying someone with better connections and more money.
Under these circumstances( 情况 ), however, he was unlikely to refuse a serious offer of immediate relief from all his money problems.
They met several times, because there was much that needed to be discussed.
Wickham of course wanted more than he could get, but at last was convinced( 被说服 ) to be reasonable.
Everything was settled between them. Mr. Darcy’s next step was to tell your uncle what was to happen.
They argued about it together for a long time, which was more than either Wickham or Lydia deserved.
But Mr. Darcy was very obstinate( 固执的 ) that he himself would pay all the money and arrange everything, and at last your uncle was forced to accept.
I think that obstinacy( 固执 ) is the real defect( 缺点 ) in Mr. Darcy’s character after all.
Instead of being allowed to help his niece, your uncle was forced to accept only the credit for it.
You may be sure, however, that he only agreed because he could see that Mr. Darcy had another interest in the affair.
When all this had been agreed upon, Darcy returned again to his friends( 朋友 ), who were still staying at Pemberley.
It was agreed that he would come to London once more when the wedding( 婚礼 ) took place, and then all the remaining money issues would also be finally settled.
Mr. Darcy returned at the proper time, and as Lydia informed you, attended( 出席 ) the wedding( 婚礼 ).
He had dinner with us the next day, and was planning to leave town again on Wednesday or Thursday.
Will you be very angry with me, my dear Lizzy, if I take this opportunity to say how much I like him?
His behavior to us has, in every respect, been as pleasing as when we were at Pemberley.
His thoughts and opinions all please me.
He needs nothing except a little more enthusiasm, and if he marries wisely, his wife can supply that.
I thought he was very sly( 狡诈的 ), because he hardly ever mentioned your name, but being sly( 狡诈的 ) seems to be the fashion( 风气 ) these days.
Please forgive me if I have made too many assumptions( 假设 ), or at least do not punish me so much that you will not invite me to Pemberley.
I will never be perfectly happy until I have been all around the grounds in a nice little carriage pulled by a pair of horses.
But I must stop writing now.
The children have been calling me for the last half hour.
Yours, very sincerely( 由衷地 ),
M. GARDINER.
The contents of this letter threw Elizabeth’s feelings( 感受 ) into great confusion( 疑惑 ).
It was difficult to decide whether she felt pleasure or pain more strongly.
She had felt some suspicion( 猜想 ) that Mr. Darcy might have been involved in her sister’s marriage, and yet, she could not believe that her suspicions( 猜想 ) had turned out to be true!
Darcy had had to beg for the help of a woman whom he must rightly hate and despise( 鄙视 ), and then to meet, time and again, negotiate( 交涉 ) with, persuade, and finally bribe( 贿赂 ),
the man whom he had always most wished to avoid, and whose very name it was punishment to him to pronounce.
Her heart did whisper that he had done it for her.
But how could his affection( 感情 ) for her—a woman who had already refused him—overcome a sentiment( 情感 ) so natural as his abhorrence( 厌恶 ) of any relationship with Wickham?
He had, to be sure, done much—she was ashamed to think how much.
But he had given a reason for his interference( 干涉 ).
It was reasonable for him to feel he had been wrong; he had the means to be generous, and though she would not consider herself to be his main reason,
she could, perhaps, believe that some remaining feelings( 感受 ) for her might make him more likely to be of help in a case that touched her so deeply.
It was exceedingly( 极其 ) painful to know that they were under obligations( 义务 ) to him that they could never repay( 偿还 ).
They owed( 欠 ) the restoration( 复原 ) of Lydia’s reputation( 名声 ), everything, to him.
Oh! How heartily( 由衷地 ) did she grieve( 难过 ) over every saucy( 无礼的 ) speech she had ever directed toward him!
For herself she was humbled( 惭愧的 ); but she was proud of him—proud that in a cause of compassion( 同情心 ) and honor, he had been able to get the better of himself.

article_info.previous: Lydia见Elizabeth对她的婚礼不感兴趣，便一定要缠着她讲述当时婚礼的情况，却不小心说出Mr. Darcy也参与了其中，Elizabeth按耐不住好奇，于是写信给舅母想要了解事实，舅母很快回了信,告诉Elizabeth是Mr. Darcy找到了Wickham和Lydia。
article_info.share_words: I think that obstinacy is the real defect in Mr. Darcy's character after all.

question.cn: 为什么Mr. Darcy要去找Mrs. Younge？
question.en: For what reason did Mr. Darcy go to see Mrs. Younge?

options.en: Because Mrs. Younge was his friend.
Because Mrs. Younge knew Lydia well.
Because Mrs. Younge knew Wickham well.

analysis: 文中提到：“He knew that Mrs. Younge knew Wickham well, and he went to her for news of him as soon as he got to town.” 所以选C。

question.en: What did Mr. Darcy try to persuade Lydia to do at first?

analysis: 文中提到：“He saw Wickham, and afterward insisted on seeing Lydia. At first he tried to persuade her to quit her present disgraceful situation.” 所以选B。

question.cn: 谁为Lydia的事情支付了所有的钱并且安排了一切？
question.en: Who paid all the money and arranged everything for Lydia?

analysis: 文中提到：“But Mr. Darcy was very obstinate that he himself would pay all the money and arrange everything, and at last your uncle was forced to accept.” 所以选B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第94天
